replies.text: Maybe I am biased but the GitHub copilot Is mostly used within VSC and there users have the choice to use other copilots. Google Gemini is free and codium as well. Giving users the ability to choose the model behind GitHub copilot is just staying competitive

There are a 100 competitors to copilot allowing the user to select from pretty much any of the major models using your own API keys, and some of them are substantially more advanced than copilot. This really feels like a reaction to tools like Cline, Cursor, Aider, etc.

Allowing Claude makes sense because its arguably the best coding AI for the cost. But allowing Gemini is surprising, doesnt Gemini exclusively run on Googles TPU hardware? Microsoft and Google are in a pretty fierce battle over who can build up the most compute infrastructure.

I dont even use gh copilot because Claude is superior I will have to try it out again now if they allow claude This is probably the reason they have been forced to do this, openai is the wrong horse to back imo
But do any of them allow whisper like speech to text, which is in chatgpt?
Is there a Claude plugin already?

The insurance for the waste is one of the biggest prohibitions to nuclear waste. It essentially needs to be guaranteed forever, this results in the only ones willing to take the risk being states and countries.

It is not 75000 years to store waste. Low and intermediate level waste is stored for 30 years in cooldown pools before being buried is ceramic pucks, and hight level waste is stored for 50 years before being buried. High level waste loses 99.9 of its reactivity in 40 years. The worst high level waste is back to background level within 100010000 years. The Navy has stored all of its waste generated over the last 60 years of nuclear power in a single spent copper mine. 95 of waste is low level. 0.2 is high level, with intermediate making up the difference. 30 percent of all used fuel is reprocessed for reuse in reactors and a small percentage is refined for medical use. As for the cost. Long term storage for is estimated 10 of the total cost of the reactors lifetime expense, and is required by the government to be set aside to cover all costs.

Nuclear waste is an extremely over exagerated problem. The entirety of highly dangerous nuclear waste produced in France from the past 40 years fits into a single cube with sides measuring 15 meters. And Its the most nuclearized country in the world, and the total amount of carbon free energy produced for so little waste is absolutely outstanding.

Fat cats just didnt have the time to get the fuel so we were told solar and other bullshit is the way. Wut? Nuke was killed by NIMBYism. The fear of another Chernobyl, TMI, etc... forced the industry to be regulated to the point that for most companies it wasnt financially viable. The company I work for used to own Talen energy mentioned in this article the reason it was sold off is because it was just dead weight back then. Perfect example...at the Susquehanna plant mentioned, we had to keep two fleets of excavators on hand in case of a meltdown and pay for upkeep, maintenance, etc... It was literally redundancy for a black swan event, wild. This is the reason that Exelon has basically been the name in the game in nuke generation in the US. My old boss used to head up exelons nuke operations the only way they were able to make it profitable was through acquisition and absolutely ruthless standardization...they acquired a new plant and would implement the playbook...execsemployees who pushed back were gone. Same service intervals, same vendors for IT systems, same schemes, same excavator, same everything across the entire fleet. My company, as many others have long said nuke is the answer...with reasonable regulation. SMR and the involvement of big tech is bringing that conversation to the forefront. On top of that, the fact is the more you engage in a risky activity the greater the odds of something bad happening from said activity even if the odds are really really low. i.e. the average driver could correctly boast having a 100 safety record, but obviously youd rightly laugh in their face if they insisted that means theres zero chance that theyll ever get into a car accident. Even if you have a bunch of very safe drivers on the road, the more very safe drivers you have on the road the greater the odds that one of those very safe drivers will get into an accident, it happens every day because theres millions of them on the road. That above paragraph isnt fear mongering about nuclear energy, its statistical odds.

Your fallacy is in attributing the causes of previous nuclear incidents all to operator error. Humans make mistakes, of course, and Chernobyl management was definitely negligent and reckless. However, what made Chernobyl a disaster was shoddy reactor design that wouldve never been possible in the West. I mean, hitting the shutdown reactor button is what caused the Chernobyl reactors to explode! Same goes to Fukushima with its backup generator design and way too tiny tsunami seawalls. Its not just the Wests operational practices that have made nuclear energy so safe here. Its that reactor facilities have been designed with passive safety in mind to prevent operator error from ever causing a disaster, and the next generation nuclear technology takes that to another level. Its like saying cars in the 50s were so dangerous because even minor accidents could kill or cause severe injury, so people just shouldnt drive. Sure, operators need to improve, but the cars themselves could get a whole lot safer, and they have!

There technical limitations to using cameras that go beyond needs more data. The point clouds created by Lidar data are precise measures, capable of operating at any level of light, and arent hampered by various sources of noise in the surroundings which can cause problems with cameras, such as lights and the like. Further, stereoscopic measurement is essentially inference IE, not a direct measure of distance or timing, but rather on an inferred model based on parallax and relationships. Lidar will always be more accurate than a camera for the simple fact that Lidar is basically a direct measurement, whereas cameras for such cases are an indirect method. You can get fairly accurate with optical cameras, but never nearly so was with Lidar. Stereoscopic and orthological mapping using cameras is processor heavy far moreso than Lidar point clouds, requires more time for data processing, requires actual light to be present, and can get confused by stray light sources. While both have limitations, particularly in rainy or foggy conditions, these limitations are generally the same. The fundamental issue with cameras for FSD isnt one of data, its one of actual technological and physical limitations which are essentially impossible to overcome.

Because that will determine if its actually a viable business model or just another silicon valley solution in search of a problem. My guess is its not. Drivers arent the only cost to a taxi business and do a lot of stuff you take for granted cleaning, arranging servicing and off duty storage etc. Self driving taxis remove the driver cost but then add in a whole bunch of extra costs cleaners, fleet managers etc plus the rather sizable costs of the extra hardware plus software and dev costs. If its viable at all it would only be at huge scale with immense capital costs. With the inevitable low margins its hard to see who that business would appeal to. The benefit to the customer is also marginal. Is your driverless taxi offering your a significantly better service or outcome than a drivered one? No. They both get you to where you want to go for a small amount of money. Thats it. And for cities they will simply make congestion even worse. America doesnt want to hear this but the solution for moving large numbers of people around quickly and cheaply is more public transport and fewer cars of any kind.

Lidar works in lowlight conditions, and is more or less a direct measure of distance. Optical methods with cameras perform poorly in low light conditions, and require orthological modeling to determine distance. A lot more can go wrong with optical cameras than Lidar in determining distances due to the far, far more strenuous processing requirements of optical systems that also tend to be far less accurate. Its a bit more apt to say that cameras dont have any particular advantage over Lidar at all aside from cost, and Lidar is a more reliable system overall with fewer fail points to be concerned with. It has some similar limitations in terms of fog and the like, but the biggest difference is that Lidar gives actual distances well, they give actual time between shooting the laser out and reading it, which is innturn calculated to a distance whereas cameras infer distances you have multiple overlapping images that create a 3D model that you can measure in.

I used to work in the technology startup world. I was a huge believer in Hydrogen and never quite sure why it didnt catch on even at the commercial trucking level. I still think theres potential there.

Companies have been promising theyre right on the breakthrough of clean, lowcost hydrogen production from splitting water for literally 30 years now. So believe it when theyre actually making huge production facilities with their technology. So far, lab breakthroughs for clean hydrogen production never actually scaled. Texas is a hydrogen hub because its an oil and gas hub, and they use leftover methane to produce hydrogen gas. This is an energy intensive process that produces a lot of CO2 and doesnt end up being better environmentally when you include all factors than just using gas. Which is why a real clean hydrogen breakthrough is so important. But again, companies have been promising cheap, clean hydrogen for decades, and Toyota and Honda went deep on spending money developing hydrogen car technology in the 1990s because they were sure hydrogen production technology would catch up soon, but so far it has not. Hopefully for the world this company is the one to do it, but I wouldnt put my own money on it.

Hydrogen is not an energy source because there is not much free hydrogen around , so usually the idea is 1. Hopefully use clean energy to make H2 from H2O wind, solar, nuclear , especially when we have excess capacity 2. Then burn it or turn it back into water in trucks or even electric generators when we need more generation The problem is storage, its hard to store. Its the smallest element and will leak out of microscopic holes that water or gas or natural gas are too big. It will crack metal over time because it will get absorbed into many metal structures. Not to mention its a gas, and to use it in any usable amounts you have to compress it under huge pressure . because of this people are working on other methods, like NH3 ammonia basically same concept but also pair the Hydrogen with Nitrogen to make ammonia , that is much easier to storetransport or even carbon what is basically natural gas but efficiency matters , we have to get hydrogen from water uses energy , then get nitrogen pull from the air, takes a lot of energy , then combine the two in a high pressure system again more energy , so while we can do this its just currently not all the efficient and it takes a whole lot of energy to make ammonia or natural gas

So far, lab breakthroughs for clean hydrogen production never actually scaled. Producing the hydrogen isnt the issue, we can produce it pretty efficiently , its storing it or transportation it in large qualities what is the issue . Its a microscopic gas what will leak out of damn near any container its so small , and unlike natural gas or propane or even ammonia it does not compress down to a liquid, what means storing it in any sort of volume is very problematic because you basically have to store it at extreme pressures . Storing gas at such high pressure , any gas is basically a bomb. It does not even have to be flammable for it to be dangerous if it explodes . To power a car it has to be highly compressed to store enough, and if you get in a car accident you dont want a tank of highly compressed gas to also explode and ripe though your car. I am not sure there is a good solution for this, so much so much of the research is trying to combine it with other things like Nitrogenammonia or carbonnatural gas so its easier to store and transport

replies.text: Thats the problemthey got it completely backward. The technology should be just a means to solve problems. LLMs are just one type of AI. There are also a lot of Machine Learning ML models that are doing very well and rely on Nvidia chips. Image processing, for example has done very well in the past 1015 years. You know that picture you took with the phone? A lot of the processing is done through MLAI models. A lot of medical devices also use this technology to improve images and remove noise. Natural language processing NLP is another you know how some systems progressively get better search results the more you use it? It uses some type of ML algorithms to learn. Sensor processing is another different one. A lot of our smart watches uses ML technology for algorithm development. ML and AI has been doing very well for a very long time, and a lot of it is hidden to the general public. LLMs are just the one that has the most visibility right now because most people dont really understand how fundamentally ingrained it is to our daytoday lives. Almost all highend technology we use these days has some data science team working on some type of algorithm that uses Machine Learning.

Occasionally it will crash and youll lose half your money, but it will scream back and youll be doubling your money before you know it. In the long term its the best investment you can make. I think what you are missing is whats already deployed in the field but no one talks about it because it literally just works. Take retail logistics for example. Walmart, Target and Amazon already have been using AI to optimize their ordering and logistics for years. It is not perfect but takes a lot of tasks off of the human who used to do it manually. Self driving cars isnt what you would expect as Amazon had done it with their warehouses. They use a selfdriving robot to move the entire shelf to a human for picking, instead of having humans run around the warehouse for picking. There isnt going to be a big overnight change as people would have imagined but rather slowly replacing humans starting from tasks until it could replace the job entirely. Likely the Internet didnt change how we lived during the dot com rush but fast forward to today, the Internet fundamentally changed how we live. AI would unfold similarly, but faster and greater than the Internet IMO. We just cant predict who is going to win from the AI revolution, just like no one thought a website that sells books in the early Internet age would become one of the largest companies on earth today.

I went to an investing conference a few weeks ago and there were AI hype presentations there as well. One of the claims was even that AI was going to start replacing entire companies! So the hype is real and pervasive. I also work with AI on a daily basis software engineer and I feel the same as OP it simply cannot do what all the hype is saying. Now as it affects investing theres a lot of money changing hands based on AI promises, so yes there is a bit of a bubble. But I believe there wont be a sudden burst of that bubble....so many companies have made significant investments into their AI infrastructures that theyll be able to pivot into more useful things when the truth about AI capabilities or lack thereof sets in. It wont just be a bunch of money lost, but they will have to redirect their resources. Yes, there are some acquisitions happening today including where I work that wont pan out in the end, so thats money lost but only for the acquirer, the equity owners of the acquired company have converted their equity into cash, which flows back into more investments, more companies, purchases in the economy, etc. So while I do believe theres a bit of overvaluation in the market based on AI hype, I dont think there will be a sudden bubble burst. It will be a slow correction, IMO, and might be marginalized by all of the other factors driving market movements, and therefore not even noticeable. IMO investing to bet against AI wont make you rich. You could make some money, yes, but probably wont be a huge win. Its a hundred percent over hyped. I heard some big shot in AWS say that in another two years you wont need software developers any more and I laughed out loud. I use GitHub copilot at work and the code is spits on is wrong most of the time. I was really hopeful, but finally gave up and shut it off because it was hurting my productivity, having to go through all the code it generated and discarding most of it. I deal with a lot of these big cloud vendors AWS, Azure, Google Cloud, MongoDB. The first thing they say when you get on a call with them for anything is have you tried our AI product. Like you get on a call with your account manager to talk about something completely unrelated you need help for and they start pitching AI until you shut them down just so you can get to the actual reason for the call. My answer is that none of our customers are clamoring for AI feature in our product or even asking for that matter, so its not a priority. I think the big tech companies will keep investing though.Microsoft started a war when they invested so heavily in Open AI. This is as much about big tech like Google, AWS, etc... protecting their turf as anything else. Its worth it for them to spend billions on Nvidia chips as insurance to protect their businesses just in case AI takes over. And the hype machine is about generating ROI for the massive investments in a technology that clearly isnt ready yet. Based on what Im seeing, were still a long way from achieving what the hypesters are promising. Doesnt mean we wont get there eventually, but its hard to predict stuff thats maybe 5 years out. Maybe it doesnt ever pan out. Seems like AI has made some leaps recently, but its been around for like 25 years and always seems to be 5 years out.
The true power of interrupting tech is when a new tech combines with another new tech thats not even invented yet.

Here is an example I asked chatGPT a specific technical information regarding a product Whats the electronic viewfinder refresh rate of a sony a6400 camera? The answer The Sony a6400 camera has an electronic viewfinder EVF with a refresh rate of 60 frames per second fps. Further question can you do it on a6300? the answer Yes, the Sony a6300 does offer an option to increase the electronic viewfinder EVF refresh rate. You can choose between two refresh rates 60 fps default 120 fps high To change the EVF refresh rate on the a6300 Go to the Menu. Navigate to the Setup tab. Look for the option labeled FINDER FRAME RATE. You can select either Standard 60 fps or High 120 fps. The higher refresh rate of 120 fps provides a smoother experience, which can be beneficial for tracking fastmoving subjects. However, it may consume more battery power. Now whats the real answer? Taken from the review website The A6400 inherits the same 2.36 million dot OLED electronic viewfinder from the A6300, which features a 120fps high frame rate setting to help track moving subjects more smoothly with virtually no lag. Further communication I think you made a mistake, because A6400 features the same EVF as the a6300 and it seems thier refresh rates can be adjusted both to 120fps. ChatGPT fallows up Youre correct, and I apologize for the confusion. The Sony a6400, like the a6300, does indeed allow you to adjust the electronic viewfinder EVF refresh rate to either 60 fps or 120 fps. To adjust the EVF refresh rate on the a6400 Go to the Menu. Navigate to the Setup tab usually represented by a toolbox icon. Find the Finder Frame Rate option. Select either Standard 60 fps or High 120 fps. The 120 fps setting provides a smoother viewing experience, particularly useful for tracking fastmoving subjects. However, keep in mind that it might lead to increased battery consumption. So yeah, all that hype for something that can bullshit you with the straight face....

So, heres my personal thought on this. And this is after watching an interview with the CEO of Google DeepMind Demis Hassabis In the short term, AI is overhyped because people are saying it will soon be able to do all these amazing things, and Hassabis says the same thing. AI is advancing quite quickly, with the next big thing being AI agents that can complete complex tasks for you, like an assistant. But thats not going to be in the short term, but moreso in the longer term. Im suspecting 45 years, personally. And that will be a big deal in terms of the tasks it can do for you. But we are not there yet. And this is similar to what Hassabis says, where longterm it may be underhyped but personally I think longer term it is just hyped. I think when companies are able to get AI agents to work, it will hit its stride. Want to also mention, that in an interview with Squawk Pod with Andy Jassy, the CEO of amazon he talked about AI, and the investments amazon is making on 3 major macro areas. One of them being for companies wanting to train their own AI models. And another for companies wanting to use existing models developed by other companies and amazon themselves. So, personally. I think we are still in the short term. Companies and developers are still learning about AI and how to make something concrete with it. Things like chatgpt and Gemini are amazingly impressive imo, but companies have not fully crystalized a way to monetize these tools and learn how to actually use them. Im looking longterm, and the companies investing in AI will benefit, assuming they make the right decisions on how to integrate with their business. But it will not be immediate, and it wont be an immediate spike in businesses but a gradual increase.

If customer A has a defect rate of 0.001, then I would argue 100 visual inspection is not needed, or at least is a waste of time. Those resources would be better spent on preventing the defects in the first place. We use an image recognition station at work to check if a glass plate is properly compressing a gasket. It works fantastically. If you really need to train an AI for a low defect rate product line, then intentionally make the defects on that product line. They dont even have to be good units. They could have something else wrong with them. You could make only the section being inspected, etc.

Case B I agree, but arent you missing the point in case A, Sorry if Im wrong since Im not an AI developer and havent dive deep in AI and machine learning probably not even the surface, but shouldnt you in case A, train based on nondefect data? You cant possibly train on defect data which in reality would be very few hence would be useless. Imo you should train with the image of nondefect which is abundant and try to recognize if its nondefect. To recognize a defect doesnt mean you need to train with defect data, you could just train to recognize nondefect with nondefect data, and decide if its a defect.

Current valuations are based off of assuming AI technology will be at a level in 25 years... where it will actually be in 20 years. Its the ageold problem. People overestimate the impact of technology in the short term, and underestimate the impact in the long term. A big reason is that it takes time for people to both refine the technology and to find the most useful ways to implement it. Internet access became a thing in the late 80s and early 90s. But the internet and modern tech did not really take over until 2010. Despite everyone recognizing that it would one day in the late 90s, and then optimistically investing as if it already had.

It sounds like you or your customers might be applying the wrong or suboptimal ML approach to solving these problems. For dents on an assembly line, simply placing cameras in a fixed position should give you the ability to collect data on the distribution of parts. You can then simply plot the deviation of your data and use classic anomaly detection methods. Cracks can be detected using basic edge detection, and erosion techniques. Machine learning would come in if the part placement relative to the camera shifts around for whatever reason. For example if you wanted to extract a mask or bounding box of the part as a preprocessing step. You can even use a model like Florence to generate embeddings and measure the distribution of the embeddings from data coming off the assembly line. For memory leaks, finetuning or an alignment oriented technique like DPO might be helpful

I see AI as very analogous to the internet during the early dotcom boom. It is very clearly a powerful technology that has worldchanging ramifications but it may take a while before we figure out the best way to leverage it and create all the necessary groundwork. I dont think AI is overhyped. Actually, I think people largely dont appreciate its full potential. However, it could still be another decade or two before we fully reach that point. When we do, however, the world will be a very different place. It will be at least as large of a leap as the internet ushered in. If youre too young to remember needing to consult an encyclopedia or filling out an order form to mail away for something you may not fully appreciate the extent to which our lives have changed postinternet and you may not realize that it all started with a 2400bps dialup connection to ASCII message boards. Thats about where AI is right now somewhere between proof of concept and marginally useful in certain applications. 20 years ago the idea that a computer would be able to recognize a random image of a cat was virtually unthinkable. Now it can not only identify a cat it can nearly instantly generate an new image of an American Wirehair holding a sparkler while flying over Mt. Fuji in a wingsuit. My programming IDE autogenerates about 25 of my code out of thin air with zero effort on my part. These are HUGE leaps, and theyve occurred very quickly. The problem with AI is really just consistency. Something that fails 510 of the time isnt particularly useful in most cases even if the results most of the time are mindblowing. But that error rate will improve with additional training. More importantly, however, is that the learning algorithms are still being refined. Very soon we may be able to reduce the required training data sets by several orders of magnitude, for example. In the short term the AI bubble may or may not burst the way the dotcom bubble did. But, long term, I expect it to be a fundamental force in virtually all aspects of modern life just as the internet has now become.

The fact that LLMs are trained on so may different fields of knowledge is part of what makes LLMs, to me, seem transformational. Recall that many of the breakthroughs in science and technology throughout history have come from combining disparate ideas from multiple disciplines and synthesizing something new. So the existing LLMs out there are very powerful tools. Full disclaimer I have a subscription to Claude.AI, and often use it as part of my work or for helping me learn. But my point was that while hardware will definitely improveand with improved hardware we may also see opportunities for improving softwareas you said, were reaching the asymptotic limit of what we can do with language and with a language model that essentially operates as a next word or next phrase predictor. And until we figure out a better theory of mind, what we got now is more or less it. That is, were going to have to shovel in more and more stuff in there for very small incremental improvements in intelligence. Its an amazing tool, and I do agree with you that it does have the power to transform our economyonce folks figure out the right ways to apply these tools. For me, I use it as a means to get some crossdisciplinary insight, which is fascinating. But as I noted before in my downvoted remarks LLMs are starting to reach an asymptote where the improvements are slowing down and becoming more incremental rather than fundamental. ... And it will require a fundamental rethinking of how AI works to move past where we are now. For example, Id love it if someone working on CoPilot would consider somehow marrying it with a toolset that can do dataflow analysis, semantic flow analysis and a method for onmachine code analysis such as variable usage as part of the underlying model. Meaning Id love it if CoPilot would not make stupid errors, like suggesting code that calls routines that are misnamed or that are guessed at, or calling out using variables that do not exist or are named differently.

Oh, I have no doubt GPUs will improve, and Im sure well see neurochips and other technologies roll out which make it possible to run large model LLMs on ever smaller and less energyintensive platforms. I personally would like to see the day when we can roll out a smallscale LLM that runs on a Teddy Ruxpinlike toy that can run enough of an LLM to hold sophisticated conversations with small children that can run off two Ccells. But from a software perspective the improvements were seeing in LLMs seem to be less fundamental and more incremental. In part, were simply hitting the limits of the philosophical theories of language and intelligenceor rather, the presumption that intelligence is strictly a linguistic construct rather than is based on an understanding of the world that is deeper than the symbols we attach to that meaning. Or, framed another way, LLMs currently do not have a model of the world or a model of how the world works essentially they predict the next word or collection of words that would go in a sentence as a response to an input collection of words. Its why there are so many examples of LLMs getting basic math wrong, or why we see things like CoPilot write shitty software because there is no understanding there. Just the manipulation of symbols. And the people currently working on the next generation of LLMs are essentially operating on the theory that if we could just shovel more shit in there, well get smarter LLMs. My own theory is that until we have a better theory of mind than the ideas from philosophical linguists, were only going to see very minor incremental improvements in what is already out there. Sure, itll be less energy intensive and eventually we may even see it run locally on portable devices. But it wont be smarter. And we already know that the way the human mind processes information is not just linguistic in nature. For example, at my alma mater, work was done to identify the clusters of neurons in the human brain that drive our ability to recognize faces. That is, you dont learn how to recognize faces after youre born from some sort of tabula rasa instead, there is builtin hardware inside the human brain which handles this recognition, and that there is a finite number of these clusters may go towards explaining why Dunbars number seems to exist.

Because LLMs fundamentally cant do what OpenAI et al claim they can and more compute doesnt change that. Without a paradigm shift that allows models to actually know things and have a concept of truth and falsity, they cant do anything more than what they currently can.
